abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Service
            Management Program Support Project for Zambia were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            unsatisfactory and borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the Bank must
            tread carefully when getting into government-led,
            multi-donor pooled funding arrangements. Government
            ownership needs to be carefully assessed in terms of
            potential for political change and risk mitigation measures
            put in place to offset its effects. Projects involving
            far-reaching institutional and behavioral change need to be
            more realistic in setting objectives, targets and
            timeframes. To ensure effective project management, there
            must be a rigorous recruitment process for key positions.
            TTLs need better support when managing such complex projects
            and should be made more aware of the resources and support
            available to them within the Bank. The achievements under
            the Service Delivery Improvement Facility (SDIF) program
            raise a fundamental question about the relative merits of
            different approaches to institutional reform/change.
